topic.title: Cross Datacenter Replication (XDCR)
topic.shortdesc: Cross Datacenter Replication (XDCR) provides an easy way to replicate data from one cluster to another.

body.p: XDCR in Couchbase Server involves replicating active data to multiple, geographically diverse datacenters either for disaster recovery or to bring data closer to its users for faster data access.

XDCR and intra-cluster replication can occur simultaneously. Intra-cluster replication is taking place within the clusters at both Datacenter 1 and Datacenter 2 while XDCR is replicating documents across datacenters at the same time. Both datacenters are serving read and write requests from the application.
body.section:
Use cases for XDCR XDCR is used mainly in these cases: for disaster recovery, to bring data closer to users and to replicate data for development and test needs.
Disaster recovery Disaster can strike your datacenter at any time â€“ often with little or no warning. The active-active cross datacenter replication in Couchbase Server ensures the availability of data 24/365 even if an entire datacenter goes down since applications can read and write to any geo-location.
Bringing data closer to users You can use XDCR to make your data available locally, with low latency. Interactive web applications demand low latency response times to deliver an impressive application experience. Therefore, the best way to reduce latency is to bring relevant data closer to the user. For example, in online advertising, sub-millisecond latency is needed to make optimized decisions about real-time ad placements.
With XDCR, you can bring the post-processed user profile data closer to ensure low latency data access.
Data replication for development and test needs Developers and testers often need to simulate production-like environments for troubleshooting or to produce a more reliable test. By using XDCR, they can create test clusters that host subset of their production data so that they can test code changes without interrupting production processing or risking a data loss.
